captions.text:
Many games have attempted to simulate the
experience of being insane, it&#39;s a tradition

going all the way back to when Pac-Man used
to ward off hallucinatory ghosts by downing
fistfuls of pills.

But none of the many video game depictions
ring authentic to genuine mental illness.

Eternal Darkness equated madness with thinking
that you&#39;re sitting on your TV remote.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent just made the screen
go a bit wibbly wobbly.

And the less said about Crazy Taxi the better,
but Ninja Theory are making a very serious

effort to tastefully dramatize insanity with
Hellblade (HURK) Senua&#39;s Sacrifice, a sort

of equal parts hack and slash / walking simulator
about a primitive warrior pulling a Dante&#39;s
Inferno on Viking mythology.

Apparently Ninja Theory even got in touch
with some actual mental health professionals

to make the portrayal of psychosis all the
more authentic, and hopefully while they had

them also work through the deep-seated issues
that made them do what they did to Devil May
Cry.

Hellblade (HURK) Setsuna&#39;s Sellotape has also
been referred to as an &#39;independent AAA&#39; game.

So already the mental illness thing is coming
across pretty well, it&#39;s got dissociative
identity disorder down fucking pat.

Anyway, the game opens with Senua, who looks
like an awkward high school girl drew all

over her face with the blue whiteboard marker
and tried to wash it off in the septic tank,

paddling her way to the entrance of the Viking
afterlife in order to rescue her lover, who

I think was murdered by Vikings, but it&#39;s
doing the standard walking simulator &#39;piece

together the backstory through vague arty
flashbacks&#39; thing, so it&#39;s hard to tell.

To say nothing of the &#39;main character is two
consent forms shy of a gang bang and might

have imagined all this and is actually carrying
around the skull of the local milkman&#39; thing.

You know, it&#39;s just occurred to me that what
with this game trying to do a very serious

portrayal of real issues that affect real
people&#39;s lives, taking the piss out of it
might make me look like a dick.

(Which is ironic, I think, because a dick
is a thing that piss comes out of).

But then I remembered, oh yeah, I&#39;ve got a
mental illness.

Phew, that means I&#39;m fully within my rights
to say that Senua&#39;s constant boggling at the

camera makes her look like a fainting goat
setting off a security light.

This very serious game about serious issues
takes itself way too fucking seriously.

And before you start clipping out that statement
to make a hilarious dance mix out of it, obviously

I wasn&#39;t expecting custard pies and a laugh
track.

What I mean is, Hellblade (HURK) Selina Scott&#39;s
attempt at po-facedness is let down by the

fact that the main character looks like a
blue-tinged dork and apparently took acting

lessons from the Scenery Chewer&#39;s Guide to
Milking It.

It&#39;s like she&#39;s only got two settings - urgent,
deer in the headlights frightened whispering,

and furious defiant screaming with teeth clenched
together like two piano keyboards in a sleeping
bag.
But let&#39;s put Senua herself to one side.
After all, that&#39;s what the camera does.
BAM, masterful link.

The core gameplay uses a Resident Evil 4-style
chase camera as we explore various deserted

nonspecifically mythic landscapes looking
for the fucking gameplay.

There is combat, it just takes a while to
find it.

And incidentally, if anything&#39;s going to undermine
the very serious message about mental illness

more than me comparing the main character
to various woodland creatures, it&#39;s a bog

standard and faintly annoying hack and slash
combat element that appears as if by magic

every now and again before vanishing just
as abruptly like a sleeping car park security

guard intermittently waking up and pretending
to work when they think their supervisor&#39;s
around.

So every now and again you&#39;ll get locked in
a room and gigantic hunky Vikings will keep

spawning in until Senua works out her issues
on their hairy nutsacks, doing the usual light

attack heavy attack dodge block counter calypso,
and it does feel kinda token, like it was

thrown in out of a sense that it had to be
there for it to be a video game, or to justify

characterising Senua as a warrior when I think
the premise would have worked perfectly well
without that element.

What does work pretty well is the whole mechanic
where a door won&#39;t open until you find a rune

in the nearby environment by standing in a
specific spot and looking at, say, a tree,

a fence post and the post-mortem erection
of a staggeringly well-endowed corpse so that
they line up into a rune shape.

That&#39;s a very fitting gameplay mechanic for
the theme because that&#39;s basically a sign

of paranoia - interpreting secret meanings
and significance where none may truly exist,

like when you hear a dog barking and take
it as an instruction to gun down your neighbours,
presumably given in a Scooby Doo voice.

Narrative and gameplay work together so aside
from everything else the combat element is

tacitly associating mental health issues with
kill-crazy violence, much the way I did just
now, and isn&#39;t that kind of reductive?

But I haven&#39;t even mentioned the other major
gimmick of Hellblade (HURK) Sausage Sizzles,

which it grandly informs you of right after
the combat&#39;s introduced: if you die too many

times throughout the course of the game, it&#39;ll
delete your progress.

Now, from a purely gameplay-focused perspective
this is of course the worst idea since Hitler&#39;s

dad started taking fertility medicine, because
it&#39;s effectively punishing the player for

requiring a normal learning curve, but from
a narrative perspective it makes a lot of

sense, because it&#39;s the sort of thing that
could potentially drive me completely up the
wall.

And you have to admit it&#39;s a ballsy fucking
move, at least on the surface.

In practice, don&#39;t be too put off by the prospect
because I died in the combat precisely once
in the entire course of the game.

You can instantly block or dodge anything
they throw at you and even if they knock you

down they all stand around swapping workout
tips waiting for you to mash the button that
makes you stand up again.

I died a bunch of other times and actually
came worryingly close to the limit, but that

was from a very annoying section where you
have to run from light to light because hanging

around in the dark too long makes you die
of, erm, being extra insane somehow.

Which is just as irritating a mechanic as
it was when Metroid Prime 2 did it.
I had no idea mental stability was solar powered.
But yeah, the combat&#39;s no threat at all.

It&#39;s actually pretty boring, since every enemy
has way too much health and you&#39;ve just gotta

slash them left and right for a while like
you&#39;re greasing up a fireman&#39;s pole.

On the whole, I feel like Hellblade (HURK)
Salty Sardines is trying a bit too hard.

Setting out with this notion of making some
terribly worthy game about mental health and

then undermining itself with overblown performances
and a main character whose backstory is so

cartoonishly fucked up that the biggest challenge
of the game is finding something to identify
with.

And then there&#39;s the combat that feels like
it&#39;s fully aware of its completely obligatory

nature and has resolved to put in as little
effort as possible until it gets fired.

By itself, the mental health thing was a nice
idea.
The norse mythology thing was a nice idea.
The hack and slashy thing was a...

well, it might&#39;ve killed an hour or two if
I were bored, drunk and paralysed below the
waist.
And the permadeath thing was certainly a thing.

But throwing all of those things in creates
a game kind of at odds with itself.
So I guess it really does capture mental illness.

All it needs is a Lexapro prescription and
a tendency to vote third party.
